source.f9e429e9:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
source.8cab358a:
# Import data from CSV file

netflix = pd.read_csv("/kaggle/input/netflix-shows/netflix_titles.csv")
source.d0fffcc4:
# Let see the dataset structure

netflix.head()
source.5f6228a8:
# Display numeric value information and datatype

netflix.describe()
source.c2065d11:
# Get percentage of null values

netflix.isnull().sum()/(len(netflix))*100
source.cbdd9b27:
# Remove director column as it has maximum null values

netflix.drop('director', axis=1, inplace=True)
source.3fcec583:
# Drop `date_added` as we don't need it in analytics
netflix = netflix[netflix['date_added'].notna()]
source.f0a0bbe6:
# Display value counts of ratings

netflix.rating.value_counts()
source.61a55cef:
# Fill null values of rating with most occuring rating
netflix.rating.fillna('TV-MA', inplace=True)
source.45e6977d:
# Year wise number of released movies/shows
plt.figure(figsize=(13,10))
g = netflix[netflix['release_year'] > 2010].release_year.value_counts().plot.bar(figsize=(10, 7))
g.set_xlabel("Release Year")
g.set_ylabel("No of Released Movies")
g.set_title("Year Wise Releases")
source.624948f3:
# Explore Movies vs TV Shows

g = netflix.type.value_counts().plot.pie(figsize=(10, 7),autopct= "%1.1f%%")
g.set_ylabel("Types")
g.set_title("Movies vs TV Shows")
source.440a166d:
# Show content distribution based on rating

plt.figure(figsize=(18,7))
g = sns.countplot(x='rating', data=netflix, palette='Blues_r', order=netflix['rating'].value_counts().index[0:15])
g.set_xlabel("Ratings")
g.set_ylabel("No of Movies")
g.set_title("Ratings Wise Counts")
source.2fb34809:
# Show content top 5 country wise ratings

plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))
top_countries = netflix[netflix['country'].isin(['United States', 'India', 'United Kingdom', 'Japan', 'South Korea'])]
g = sns.histplot(x='rating', y='country', data=top_countries)
g.set_xlabel("Ratings")
g.set_ylabel("Countries")
g.set_title("Top 5 country wise ratings")
source.f9752e75:
# Top 10 oldest TV Show

netflix[netflix['type'] == 'TV Show'].sort_values('release_year')[0:10]
source.7fc835dc:
# Extract month from date_added column
netflix['month'] = pd.to_datetime(netflix['date_added']).dt.month
source.f44de18f:
# Show content distribution based on rating

plt.figure(figsize=(18,7))

g = sns.countplot(x='month', data=netflix)
g.set_xticklabels(['January','February','March','April',
                   'May','June','July','August','September','October','November','December'])
g.set_xlabel("Months")
g.set_ylabel("No of Movies")
g.set_title("Month wise releases")
source.970d2ca2: # <font size="3">**3.3 Content distribution based on rating**</font>
source.d6e11927:
Netflix is one of the top OTT platforms in this time. This notebook contains analytics of Netflix Shows and Analytics based on contents. I have used Seaborn for visual charts 1. Import Libraries & Data 2. Missing data analysis 3. Exploratory Data Analysis
3.1 Year wise number of released movies/shows
3.2 Explore Movies vs TV Shows
3.3 Content distribution based on rating
3.4 Top 5 country wise ratings
3.5 Top 10 Movies and TV Shows
3.6 Duration analysis
**Data Structure**
show_id - object
type - object
title - object
director - object
cast - object
country - object
date_added - object
release_year - int64
rating - object
duration - object
listed_in - object
description - object
source.5cd32b07: # <font size="3">**3.5 Top 10 Movies and TV Shows**</font>
source.89707526: As we can see, only release_year is numeric column. other columns are object type only
source.908e25d5: As per obversation there 29% directors are missing or null. Country and cast also have 9% null values
source.9e4be022: Number of movies release is comparatively higher than the TV Shows
source.a75612fe: Comparing to other months, more Movies and TV Shows are released in July and December month
source.bcfbb1c2: In this part i displayed various type of data visulizations using seaborn. You can use other visulization libraries too
source.83ff3dd4: Please upvote if you liked the kernel! It motevates me :)
